items.title: What if you wrote every agent from scratch?
items.content:
You'd face: Months of prompt engineering per domain.
Why this fails: 99-Agents has 108 tested specialists. You'd reinvent wheels.
Hidden constraint: Specialization is expensive to create, cheap to use.

items.title: The irreducible selection
items.content:
Know tech, need implementation: One domain agent from 99-Agents
Starting fresh: BMAD Quick Flow (Barry)
Everything else: Refinement for scale and quality.

items.title: All three ecosystems share INV-005: Specialization beats generalization
items.content: Whether 99-Agents, BMAD, or Claude-007, all provide specialized agents over generalists. The invariant: focused expertise > broad knowledge for production tasks.

items.title: Three Ecosystems = Hiring Strategies
items.content:
99-Agents = Hiring contractors by skill (need React? Hire React expert)
BMAD = Hiring a complete team (PM, architect, devs, QA)
Claude-007 = Hiring from a staffing agency (they assess and place)

If you've hired teams, you already understand agent ecosystems.

items.title: One constraint -> FIVE ecosystem designs
items.content:
ROOT: LLMs have limited context windows
-> Agents must be specialized (smaller prompts)
-> Specialization must be reusable (ecosystems)
-> Ecosystems need organization (by domain OR phase)
-> Organization needs invocation patterns (plugins OR personas)
-> Invocation needs orchestration (CLAUDE.md rules)

items.title: BMAD: 30.7k GitHub stars
items.content: The most starred agent methodology. Users report 50-90% time savings on SDLC phases. "By story 10, Winston knew our architecture patterns."

items.title: Domain Catalog vs Methodology Agents
items.content:
Domain (99-Agents): Deep tech expertise, but no project structure
Methodology (BMAD): Clear SDLC phases, but fixed 9 personas

WHY NO PERFECT ANSWER: Different problems need different organizations.
Heuristic: Know what to build? Domain. Don't know? Methodology.

items.title: How deep is your agent understanding?
items.content:
Beginner: "What agents exist?" -> The three ecosystems
Intermediate: "When to use each?" -> Domain vs methodology
Advanced: "How to combine?" -> BMAD phases + domain agents
Staff: "Cost optimization?" -> Model tiering, progressive disclosure
Expert: "Cross-ecosystem orchestration?" -> Shared state, CLAUDE.md rules

items.title: If you use Opus for everything
items.content:
IF: Route all tasks to Opus (most capable)
THEN: Costs 10x what Haiku would cost
THEN: Hit rate limits faster
THEN: Slow down development
FINALLY: $500/day instead of $50/day

Fix: Model tier by task complexity. Haiku for grep, Opus for architecture.

items.title: BMAD + 99-Agents
items.content:
Works: Yes, the most powerful configuration.
How: BMAD controls phases 1-3, 99-Agents domain experts for phase 4.
The danger: Context bloat if you load too many agents.
Recommendation: Load domain agents on-demand, not all upfront.

items.title: At 50+ agents, orchestration becomes the bottleneck
items.content:
At 10 agents: Manual invocation works
At 50 agents: Need naming conventions, categories
At 100+ agents: Need automated routing, topology selection

Threshold: ~50 agents. Beyond this, consider Claude-Flow or Swarms.

items.title: Agent ecosystem value over time
items.content:
Day 1: "Why do I need 108 agents? I just want to code."
Week 1: "The security-auditor found 3 issues I missed."
Month 1: "I invoke specialists without thinking."
Month 6: "My velocity is 3x what it was."

Don't judge ecosystems by day 1.

items.title: How agent selection degrades
items.content:
100% -> 90%: Wrong ecosystem, suboptimal but works
90% -> 70%: Wrong agent within ecosystem, weaker output
70% -> 50%: Wrong model tier, cost/quality mismatch
50% -> CLIFF: Conflicting agents, context pollution

Critical: Selection errors compound. Fix early.

items.title: What if all agents were generalists?
items.content:
You'd get: Superficial knowledge across domains.
Why this fails: A React generalist doesn't know hooks deeply. A security generalist misses OWASP edge cases.
Hidden constraint: LLM capacity is finite. Specialization trades breadth for depth.

items.title: If enterprise agents aren't right
items.content:
Need simpler? -> Single Claude session with good CLAUDE.md
Need self-learning? -> Claude-Flow (SONA architecture)
Need 1000+ agents? -> Swarms framework
Need overnight autonomy? -> Ralph pattern

items.title: When plugin count flips from help to hurt
items.content:
1-5 plugins: Pure benefit (specialization helps)
5-10 plugins: Diminishing returns (context starts filling)
10-15 plugins: Neutral (benefit equals overhead)
15+ plugins: Net negative (context starves your code)

THE INFLECTION: ~10 plugins loaded simultaneously
Detection: Claude forgetting instructions? Check plugin count.

items.title: If you skip orchestration rules in CLAUDE.md
items.content:
IF: No orchestration rules for multiple ecosystems
THEN: Multiple agents respond simultaneously
THEN: Conflicting advice
THEN: Context pollution compounds
FINALLY: System unusable, restart required

Fix: "Only one agent active at a time unless explicitly multi-agent"

items.title: UNSOLVED: Cross-ecosystem state sharing
items.content:
The question: How should BMAD workflow-status.yaml interact with 99-Agents skill state?
Why it's hard: Each ecosystem has its own state format.
Current best practice: Manual coordination via CLAUDE.md rules.

items.title: Fixed Roster vs Unlimited Scale
items.content:
THE DILEMMA:
BMAD (9 fixed): Clear roles, but what if you need agent #10?
Swarms (1000+): Unlimited scale, but which topology?

WHY NO PERFECT ANSWER: Structure and flexibility are opposed.
Heuristic: Use BMAD until you need more; then add domain agents.

items.title: Understanding ecosystem lock-in
items.content:
Beginner: "Just pick one ecosystem"
Intermediate: "What if I need capabilities from another?"
Advanced: "How do I integrate without chaos?"
Staff: "What's the migration path if ecosystem X dies?"
Expert: "How do I abstract over ecosystems?"

items.title: Seth Hobson (99-Agents creator)
items.content: "Each plugin does one thing well. Unix philosophy applied to AI agents. The result: 72 plugins that compose rather than compete."

items.title: Ecosystem Selection = Restaurant Choice
items.content:
99-Agents: Specialty restaurant (best sushi in town)
BMAD: Full-service restaurant (appetizer to dessert)
Claude-007: Food court (one-stop, many options)

Match the ecosystem to the meal you need.

items.title: All Three Ecosystems Combined
items.content:
Works: Yes, but high complexity.
How: BMAD for phases, 99-Agents for domain, Claude-007 for choreography.
The danger: Three different invocation patterns, three state systems.
Recommendation: Only for teams with dedicated orchestration expertise.

items.title: Selection criteria share INV-001: Match tool to task
items.content: Whether choosing ecosystems, agents within ecosystems, or model tiers, the same invariant applies: "The right tool for the task, not the most powerful tool available."

items.title: At enterprise scale, ecosystem choice affects hiring
items.content:
At 1-5 devs: Ecosystem is personal preference
At 10-20 devs: Ecosystem becomes team standard
At 50+ devs: Ecosystem affects onboarding, training, hiring

Implication: Your ecosystem choice is a long-term infrastructure decision.
